description.narrative: Medical Stores Limited (MSL) is a government owned institution that is mandated to procure, store and distribute pharmaceuticals and medical supplies to public health institutions in Zambia. Sweden has provided support directly to Medical Stores Limited (MSL) since 2009. This intervention, which is an exit strategy for the Embassy, is intended to provide bridge funding to provide short term operational support as well as technical assistance for the development of a plan for a self-sustaining entity. The Embassy will consider a separate contribution to engage a consultant to support the latter. The intervention will enable MSL to continue to deliver on essential medicines and medical supplies while creating the resources, platform and framework to enable MSL to generate its own income sustainably.

Medical Stores Limited (MSL) är en statlig institution med uppgift att köpa in, lagra och distribuera läkemedel och medicinsk utrustning till hälsokliniker i Zambia. Sverige har gett ekonomiskt stöd till MSL sedan 2009. Denna insats ämnar överbrygga ett kortsiktigt finansieringsgap för operativa kostnader samt tekniskt stöd till framtagandet av en strategi för att uppnå MSLs mål att bli en självförsörjande institution. Insatsen kommer att försäkra att MSL kan fortsätta att distribuera livsviktiga mediciner och utrustning. Den kommer också att utveckla MSLs strategi till att generar intäkter.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Overall stock levels of essential medicines was good performing slightly above target according to the health management information systems reports. However regional differences exist in stock levels indicating persistent problems in last mile distribution of drugs despite the regional hubs. ´The quality of the reporting can also be questioned for some of the regions. More effort is required to improve stock management at the lowest level and communication between MSL and their clients. For vaccines, cold chain was one of the most common reason for non-availability of stock. The National Supply Chain strategy outlines key issues that need to be implemented by government in order to improve supply and availability of essential medicines. This strategy which is yet to be implemented is a key piece in ensuring sustainable results in this area. Sida’s support to MSL focused only on one part of the supply chain puzzle and for a limited time only. The strategy needs to be implemented in full in order to improve supply of essential medicines and supplies.
The second result "To facilitate the formation and implementation of a framework of commercial solutions spanning the breadth of the supply chain from procurement to the last mile that guarantees sustainable supply chain services to the health delivery system" was too ambitious for the time frame of the project. MSL worked with consultant for nearly six months to come up with a concept note for commercialisation but could not take it further to develop a business plan and model for implementation during the limited time frame.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
